item.title: Why Use EasyBCD When You Have GRUB
item.description: When you set up a dual-boot system, one of the most common hurdles is managing the boot process — specifically, selecting which operating system to boot into. This is where GRUB (Grand Unified Bootloader) steps in. If you’ve ever faced the hassle of relying on third-party tools like EasyBCD to change between operating systems, GRUB is the solution. In this article, we’ll explore how GRUB works, how it simplifies dual-booting, and some of its more advanced features that can enhance your experience.

item.title: How To Connect To WiFi Via Terminal
item.description: Do you remember the meme, which goes, “I’m connecting to my WiFi using terminal, my friends…HACKER”? I have never seen anyone doing that in real life. But nowadays I have a strong reason to do that in the presence or absence of my friends. For some strange reason, my desktop environments keep breaking the much needed nm-applet. For those who may not know, generally speaking, nm-applet is the WiFi icon that you see on the top or bottom right of your screen; when clicked shows the WiFi networks available nearby.

item.title: Arrays Are Powerful In Bash
item.description: “$” might symbolize dollars to many of you, but for bash users it’s the holy grail for retrieving stored data. Speaking of which, do you know what’s the common place to store a piece of data? A variable. Variable The name itself incurs that variable is something that could be varied. So is it like a chameleon that changes colors all the time? Not precisely, if you remember from the intro its a common place to store a piece of data.
